thread.title: RAF planes scrambled to intercept flight from Romania to Birmingham
thread.title_full: RAF planes scrambled to intercept flight from Romania to Birmingham

author: Chloe Chaplain
title: RAF planes scrambled to intercept flight from Romania to Birmingham
text:
Tuesday 7 March 2017 10:50 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Jets: The RAF planes intercepted the flight as it entered UK airspace MOD Crown Copyright 2017 
RAF fighter jets were scrambled to intercept a plane flying from Romania to the UK after it lost communication with ground control. 
The jets were sent to escort the plane flying from Bucharest after it ran into technical difficulties in UK airspace on Tuesday morning. 
The freight plane, which contained three crew and no passengers, was met by two Typhoon jets scrambled from RAF Coningsby, Lincolnshire, and a Voyager aircraft launched from Brize Norton, Oxfordshire. 
The plane was guided safely to Birmingham Airport just after 7.30am. 
An RAF spokesman said: "The Royal Air Force can confirm that Typhoon aircraft from RAF Coningsby, Lincolnshire were launched this morning on a quick reaction alert mission to intercept a civilian aircraft that had lost communications. 'Drones should be banned from sky near airports' 
"The aircraft was safely escorted to Birmingham International Airport." 
A Birmingham Airport spokeswoman said: "We can confirm that a private Saab 340 aircraft inbound from Bucharest to Birmingham and carrying three crew encountered communication difficulties during a flight earlier today. 
"In accordance with normal operating procedures the aircraft was intercepted by military jets on arrival into UK airspace and was escorted up to its scheduled arrival into Birmingham." 
The RAF has Typhoon pilots on standby 24 hours a day to defend UK air space which can be launched within minutes to intercept aircraft. 
Causes for concern could be Russian military aircraft or civilian planes which have stopped communicating with air traffic control or have sent an emergency signal. 
Ministry of Defence figures show emergency response planes were launched on 12 days in 2015, eight in response to Russian aircraft and four to investigate other planes. More about:
